comments.commentBody: Hands down Patrick Barry is my favorite constructor. That's not meant as a slight to any other puzzle master but I'm in Patrick's wheelhouse (or he's in mine). It's probably because my ego gets a big boost when I solve one of his puzzles. It's Friday, it's a romp with sly and fun clues. I loved LAPCAT, the wicked KNEED and TALKING HEAD. I didn't know FAITH NO MORE (after watching the clip, I can't imagine why) but got it on the crosses. Loved it all.
so it should be a popularity contest?

They last so long so that every last dime can be wrung out by news networks, campaign staffers, hotels, convention centers, & advertizers. I read a book about William McKinley. He was running against famous orator, William Jennings Bryan, & knew he couldn't hold a candle to his speaking style. So, he spent the entire campaign season on his front porch, spending no money & making the media come to him. Guess what? He won. Too bad we don't do that any more. In Great Britain, the campaign season lasts 6 weeks.

They last so long because campaigns are good for "business" and enrich thousands of businesses around the country and the world.
In short -- it's all about the MONEY -- it's always all about the MONEY.

Remind me again why our elections last so long? The only positive I see is that they allow time for less-known candidates such as Sanders to gain recognition and momentum. In return, we get greater polarization, millions upon millions of dollars wasted on advertisements, and hate-spewing egoists like Trump clawing their way out of dismissive ridicule and into positions at the front of their party's nomination.
I agree.  His voice and lecturing tone really grates on my nerves.  He never really smiles unless he is scoring a point against someone.
He'd be 79 after one term!

Does Bernie Sanders really think he can beat the Republican candidate once the GOP machine starts actively conflating his socialism with communism, and once they start a whispering campaign about his Jewishness with all the negative stereotypes involved? (The latter would have to be done completely behind closed doors.) Does he really believe that Americans would elect someone who would be 78 years old after only one term?

I don't believe Sanders really has the welfare of the American people completely at heart. He's not pure as the driven snow, and I believe there's a massive amount of ego involved (similar to Trump, perhaps?).

If Sanders really wanted to change America he would have done it by now. He could still achieve a great deal by leading his "revolution" from outside government, as did the great Gandhi and Martin Luther King.

Something stinks here, and Sanders is looking less and less attractive all the time.

I can barely stand to hear his voice anymore.

If you're to blame anyone for the Iraq war, blame Nader and his supporters. You can also blame Nader and his supporters for 911 as well.  If you don't believe in regime change, then let a regime change not happen in the US in 2016!  Vote Hillary Clinton to keep the ball rolling in the right and best direction for this country. She is the most qualified to be POTUS!

And it matters because she is running for president unlike most of those pols who voted yes, in fact, that's WHY she voted yes, for her future presidential run, so she would not appear weak as woman candidate.

I always thought and hoped a woman president who brings life into this world would not so easily take it. Would be more of dove like Bernie.

Makes me want to puke.

Forget the repeated claims Bernie shouts or offers pie in the sky or that Hillary is strident or she's tough, seasoned, the most qualified person ever to run for president. This isn't what matters. Bernie's not calling her unqualified because he's a misogynist and hates women - that's ridiculous and false.

Bernie's called her unqualified because of her very bad decisions on the Iraq War vote and regime change in iraq, the two most significant destabilizing foreign policy disasters in recent history. Decisions which resulted in political chaos and the rise of terrorist states in the middle east, endangering Europe, North Africa and the United States. Decisions which led to the loss of American lives - the lives of our troops, our allies, & tens of thousands of innocent civilians.

Hillary made these decisions about the Iraq War (which was a no-brainer to anyone paying attention!) and regime change in Libya after being presented with facts and careful consideration. These weren't dumb remarks she made on the campaign trail while exhausted. These decisions are the most important things she's running on - that she's the person we should trust to answer that 3 a.m. phone call that there's a crisis somewhere in the world that the U.S. president must respond to. And her record shows that in these 2 most important situations in recent times, while she held important office as senator or in the cabinet, she made terrible, destructive choices that had tragic, ongoing consequences.

If you had lived through all the Clinton years as I have you would not be surprised at all, they do worse and it will come.

Bernie has every right to defend himself, he must, and on certain issues, fire back. He is used to wrestling alligators in Washington. Politics is ugly, hrc and bill do stupid stuff like this when threatened (oh my and worse). Watch.

And you give excellently with your astute, balanced, well-written comments. Thank you.
Bernie 2016

@Tiffany,
This time, I agree with you.

4-8-16@4:27 am

From suggesting Sanders is not qualified to saying that he didn't 'prioritize' women's rights in abortion to exploiting the Flint water crisis and the tragedy at Sandy Hook, I am appalled at Clinton's tactics. On the surface, these moves almost seems too greasy and too corrupt to be from her campaign, but yet she continues to smear her opponent rather than talk about the issues that make many Americans wary of voting for her.

What did she say to Wall Street that they gave her so much money? Why is she still holding fundraisers with special interest groups and the rich when Americans detest campaign finance? Until Clinton can muster the courage and integrity to address these issues with at least some authenticity rather than condescension and rhetoric, many Americans will see her as an extension of the rich and the establishment.

If Clinton comes out and says "This is how the system is, and that is why I am forced to fund raise in this way. I am sorry. From this day on, I will no longer accept money from X, Y, and Z." This is authenticity and a fearlessness needed in our next president, and I doubt Clinton or her campaign advisers would agree to do such a thing that would require character and insight. Instead, they will double down on their smear campaign and detract from her weakness as a candidate.

That is why I hope Bernie Sanders continues on with his integrity and his passionate anger. I will continue to give and give to his campaign because we deserve better.

Why does every one have to explain what Sanders "means"?  Can't he put together an articulate explanation or position on anything?    So choosing the wrong word, or not being able to explain how to achieve his goals, is just another chance for his supporters to tell us what he really means or what he meant to say.  That is just pitiful.  He is not in Vermont anymore-- put a sentence together Sir!

You're tying yourself in knots trying to distinguish between Bernie saying she is "disqualified" for various reasons but not that she is "unqualified". I respect Bernie, but today I have slightly less respect for him than I did yesterday. He did not have to go down this road.
My God, she is the most honest of any of the candidates that we have, including Sanders and the most qualified.

He didn't actually mean she was unqualified, he meant that her acceptance of campaign contributions from the financial services industry, the petroleum industry, the insurance industry and the pharmaceutical industry disqualify her because of the debts she's amassed with them that will come due if she reaches the White House. It's simply not the same thing - few question her qualifications, many question her honesty.

While I respect your views on Secretary Clinton, I find it horrifying and offensive that you'd suggest Sanders' supporters are falling for Republican rhetoric. I have never voted for a Republican in my life, I find the current GOP rhetoric horrifying, and I don't watch FOX and co., nor do I read any right-wing media. I find Hillary untrustworthy because she claims to be for campaign finance reform while engaging in and benefitting immensely from the Citizens United decision. I find her untrustworthy because she claims to be for tougher regulation of Wall St. while holding fundraisers and having given $225K speeches to their elite. I could go on.

While I don't doubt that she is a hundred times better than any of the Republicans running today and I'll vote for her easily in November, Bernie is raising issues that resonate with millions of Democrats, and while he trails her significantly in delegates, many of us have and will continue to vote for him until June because we believe in his message and his integrity. Don't try to sweep these valid criticisms of her under the rug by claiming that they're manufactured by Republicans.

I have always voted Dem because I agreed far more with their stances on the issues, but I've always identified as an Independent. I even changed my party affiliation to vote for Sanders this month. It's a sad day when Democrats try to discount Sanders supporters by claiming they naively believe right-wing rhetoric.

The most compelling thing about Bernie’s campaign was that it might actually be possible to be outside politics as usual, and, for a sweet quixotic moment, made me actually dare to hope for something different. But the strains of  campaigning and the long overdue vetting have revealed him to be exactly like any other politician, but maybe worse, because he is wrapped in so much sanctimony. It must be incredible to finally find oneself a rock star at 74, and I am sure these are the best moments of his life, but he is seriously in over his head. For the first time last night I donated to Hillary’s campaign and I have noticed a similar subsiding of enthusiasm all over the internet.

Bernie is not saying that Hillary is not theoretically qualified. One only has to be a "natural born citizen" and be 35 years of age. Hillary has a resume of many years in the political business that would be impressive if time spent at something is all that matters. What she lacks is good judgement and integrity. Bernie is saying that she disqualifies herself by all the bad decisions she made such as supporting the Iraq war, promoted the Lybian war, wants to go to war with Syria, supported all those destructive trade deals, accepting millions of dollars from firms that could benefit from her decisions and so on. She had the qualification but she forfeited them.

You can always cherry pick anyone, and a lot what your saying is either Republican attacks (email) or Bernie attacks. Bottom line is she has worked a lot harder, knows the end and outs of Washington, knows how to fight money, is honest about what can realistically be done, than Sanders, thus is far more qualified to lead this country.

I read many comments from Bernie supporters claiming they will never vote for Hillary because of her vote for the Iraqi war resolution.

John Kerry also voted for that resolution.

Did those self-same Bernie supporters sit out the 2004 election? If they did, they are fools who gave us another four years of the W wrecking ball.

Or, understanding the stakes, did they go ahead and give Kerry their vote? While boasting today, when the stakes are horrifyingly higher, that they would not do the same for Hillary?

To call them “fools” would insult fools.

I did vote for John Kerry, and I will (reluctantly) vote for Hillary in November, if she is the nominee.  But look where John Kerry evolved since 2003: as Secretary of State, he has taken the US on a different path from the regime-change policies of Secretary Clinton.  That speaks to the kind of judgment that we seek, the ability to not only 'apologize' for the incorrect vote, but also change course and abandon the old perspective that lay behind that incorrect vote.

What are the qualifications for the presidency? One has to be at least 35, a natural born citizen of the US, and have resided within the US for 14 years. So by those criteria, both Hillary and Bernie are qualified. But of course what both are talking about is whether the other has the mettle to become a good president. Hillary points to her resume, as thought heaping one more accomplishment, one more activity polishes her credentials for the office. But we all know people whose resumes are replete with exceptional experience but whose judgment, whose moral fiber is wanting. And this is what Bernie and so many of us are saying. We keep returning to the Iraq resolution, because even though 2003 was a trying time when many of her constituents were afraid and wanted to strike out in retaliation, as Senator, her job was not to vote for the politically expedient thing, but to show leadership and do the right thing. Her hawkish positions as Secretary of State show that she hadn't learned that lesson, and her actions since 2012 -- the email server, her decision to sell herself to the highest bidders on Wall Street, her late criticism of Keystone and TPP -- all speak to serious lapses in judgment. I prefer a president whose ethics and trustworthiness are above reproach, because the rest of the job can be learned; trust and character are nurtured from childhood.

As a private citizen, she is allowed to make those speeches and be paid for them and by the way, she makes the same or less than other folks with the same expertise or credentials which makes them of interest for a seminar.

Sanders has proven, through his interviews, that he doesn't really have a grasp on the important issues of today. It is one thing to declaim about the country's woes, it's another to be able to address them.

And then there is the question of the Sanders' FEC filings. When will his campaign clarify the millions of unaccounted for dollars? Sanders seems to be in this for the money and less in it for the people.

This is a little kerfluffle based on media reports and headlines that may have been misunderstood by one or another of the two candidates,  it is nothing compared to the mess in the Repiblican Party and is just another attempt by the news people and Clinton apologists to create something out of nothing. Again they come to the defense of their candidate, Hillary, threatened  by a mythical misogynist rival. The journalists and supporters pretend that questions about her character and judgement are not relevant to the campaign.  The sports metaphors in the campaign have now gone from horse racing to boxing since mudslinging doesn't seem to be a recognized Olympic event yet. Mrs. Clinton pulled the same kind of stuff in 2008 against Obama, insinuating among other things that he was an inexperienced candidate with just a pretty speech.

The Clintons have always played dirty, so spare us this sanctimony. Just google "Bill Clinton + Obama + 2008" and you will see that they are using the same vile playbook they used against then Senator Obama when he was challenging Mrs. Clinton for the nomination.

"Two years ago this man would have been carrying our bags and bringing us coffee..." That is how Mr. Clinton disparaged Mr. Obama.

The internet is a wonderful thing.

Um... you do realize the point of elections is to actually contrast yourself against the other candidate, right? Make a case why your campaign has the better platform? There is no disconnect between his means and his message.

So he should resign from the race and let a person win the nomination who is indebted to special interests, corporations and Wall Street, votes for unjustified war and lacks trustworthiness and good judgement all because he said "She is indebted to special interests, corporations and Wall Street, votes for unjustified war and lacks trustworthiness and good judgement"

That makes no sense

I respected Sanders earlier this year when he was not pointing fingers to Clinton. He wasn't attacking her emails nor he was questioning her speech fees. At that time he didn't want to participate in a negative campaigning as it was with republicans.

However, I believe it was around the Michigan primary, Sanders started to attack Clinton about free trade agreements, emails, and speech fees from GS. His popularity increased as a consequence. But his purer ideals fell.

Now he's even saying that Clinton is not qualified. I think he has fallen too far. If he wants to save what he says he stands for, then he should resign from the race.

I prefer Sanders credentials. He is against going to war. Whether he busts up the banks or not, I don't think they would continue to operate as they do currently. Companies that are too big to fail ARE too big. He thoughts ruminate form the vantage point of the citizen, voter, people. He's got no grandfather type backers to ease the way for him to become President. It's what he's done and what he says he will do.

Contrasted against Clinton who is fine with the banks as they are and corporate owners who are contributing to her Super PACs. If she told me she wasn't and would change them, I would not believe her. She did vote for the Iraq War. How many hundreds of thousands of NYers marched against it? She has said it was a mistake. Yes, it was! A costly one that we have not stopped paying for yet. She is a Hawk, not a smart power advocate. It's her "smarter than thou" attitude that gets in her way all of the time. She'd take this nation to war just to prove that she could. She's driven. Driven to become President no matter what it takes. I think what disqualifies her is that she felt she was going to sail into the Presidency as if she was owed it. Her air of entitlement disqualifies her.

Anyone, Trump as a prime example, who after 15 years has not succeeded to the Presidency (both he and Clinton have desired the role for many years) does not mean there is a swell for them to do so now. Clinton is smart. Sanders is smart. I prefer Sanders smart for today's challenges.

And what has Sanders done?  I can't stand the criticizing when no one has been in the positions she's held. She was not the only one the voted for the Iraq war.  Many senators respected Senators did. She had said it was a mistake. Sanders voted to fund the war. She was an excellent SOS and a very good NY senator.  What has Sanders done?

It's surprising that Bernie has held off for so long given Sec. Clinton's many failures. The narrative that Clinton is highly qualified defies empirical evidence.  Yes, she has been in the public arena for three decades but her actions have been marked by poor judgement and failure beginning with the botched attempt at health care reform in the first years of the Clinton admin. when the Dems had majorities in the House and Senate, her vote for the Iraq War, and while Sos pushing for regime change in Libya, Syria, Ukraine and setting off a firestorm in large swaths of the world.  All that while pandering to Wall Street and corporate interests and raking in huge sums in speaking fees from same. We can ill afford more of that kind of experience in the White House.

You do recognize that, prior to Sanders' remarks, Clinton had questioned Sanders' qualifications, right?  That's the Bernie Sanders who has about 30 years in elected office, from mayor of a small city to a U.S. Senator.  Where is your outrage at Clinton's initial, unwarranted remarks?  And to throw in the word "misogny"? It's a strong and pointed word--let's try to use it when appropriate.  Otherwise, what words should we be flinging at Clinton for starting this spat?

Presidency is a great responsibility, not a corporate job. People with great honesty, conviction deserve it.HRC does not have either. If US is going to get its first women president, she should be a inspiring leader not some one who says anything to become a president. We can wait for a better candidate.

George Bush was a failure at every position he held -- even the ones the financed by his GHW Bush's friends. He served as the governor of Texas -- one of the weakest governorships in the country -- and he was AWOL from his pathetic position in the Texas Air National Guard -- but if Al Gore had said flat out that "George Bush is unqualified to be president" the media and the GOP would have gone into maniac mode attacking Gore and tearing him to shreds for even whispering it let alone saying it loudly in an interview. It's definitely a dog-whistle from Sanders.
I wouldn't vote of Sanders just for the fact that he sat on his axx in the Senate for years until he was 74 before he decided to do any of the heavy lifting to put himself in the forefront of American politics -- meanwhile people like Hillary Clinton has been in the thick of it for years -- many times being attacked not for anything she did but because people were angry with her husband for personal failures on his part. Clinton stood up to all of it and she's running again -- even after suffering a defeat in 2008 that no one thought was possible. That's a strong woman of conviction that she has something to bring to the table as President -- I'll vote for Hillary Clinton -- not the old guy who hid in the Senate for many years and only emerged when he was 74 -- a time when he should be retiring not looking for a new job.

I have to agree with another post. Many, many women have seen a job, a promotion or other recognition go to a male co-worker in the guise that they male was more qualified--even in the face of facts to the contrary. So saying that a female past Senator of New York and Secretary of State of the United States is unqualified to be President is really misogynistic. He could simply not do this with a straight face had HRC was male--no matter the record of the Senator and former Secretary of State.
I am a 63 year old female that lived this in Silicon Valley and in scientific research earlier in my career. Woman my age can hear the dog whistle! Stop in Mr. Sanders--we all vote!!!

Several US presidents didn't hold many "qualifications" when they first ran for president. Obama was in the Senate two years, and had served a couple of years as a state legislator. Eisenhower never held elective office before becoming president. Same with Andrew Jackson. Theodore Roosevelt was vice-president for six months when an assassination made him president--he had never held a federal post before. And Abraham Lincoln had served two years as a Congressman in the House, and then he had failed to reelect.

The president sets the tone and direction of the administration and communicates with the people and with foreign leaders. The technocrat advisers and bureaucrats in the administration fine-tune policy and carry out the executive functions.

What's important to me is where a candidate stands on the issues, and the strength of their character.

It's a big deal over nada.

I hope Bernie tells them to go fish. That's the Trump "polite" and "nice" way to do it. Yet Bernie is actually right. From every appearance, Mrs. Clinton hardly evinces a hanging-chad of comprehension of her husband's work as president.

I hope his wife didn't mean it when she mentioned to Rachael Maddow today that he would support Clinton if he loses. Sanders should run as an independent. Trump probably will, too, if he loses to that Canadian Senator. And Sanders will probably win, nevertheless!

The two party structure is a joke, and hopefully it will mean the end of the two party experiment and extended debacle in the United States.

There is nothing impractical about what Sanders wants to do except that so many Democrats have drunk the Republican Cool Aid that they now believe that there is no money and that we should be giving tax cuts to billionaires instead of investing in our people. Centrists are a bunch of suckers doing the bidding of global corporations without (in most cases) even realizing it.
Fight for what is right instead of constantly giving away more and more in the vain hope that the lunatic right will ever be satisfied. It hasn't worked for thirty years and it never will.

I think there is substantial evidence that Mrs. Clinton may have the MOST honesty and integrity of the candidates.

She was tops in an unbiased evaluation of all 15 on Climate Change, one of the top issues of our time. http://bigstory.ap.org/article/3e946f29fa534a0b9c1d064b16e06b61/ap-fact-...

She has long had detailed policy positions on her website - transparent to voters, more than any other candidate. And most importantly, scads of economic and tax policy analysts have long said that she's the only one whose numbers add up.

I'll forgive all of the candidates a bit of spin when it comes to framing themselves in the most favorable light. And I understand that Sen. Sanders is a working Senator and can't be equally prepared, but he's had ample funds to hire folks to re-work his numbers and hasn't. He will not win the general election with the tax rates that he is proposing... but I fear he may have handed the GOP an election they had all but conceded.
That's reprehensible.

If you think you are "sick of business as usual" wait until you see what a Republican President can do with a Republican Congress.  Then you, and all of the rest of us, will discover what "sick" really feels like.

"Many, like me, who see no meaningful difference between Mrs. Clinton and ANY Republican, will vote for the Republican, in order to force the political situation in America closer to its crisis."

No intelligent thinking person would make that statement "force the political situation in America closer to its crisis" -- so you'd rather see the country crash and burn with millions of people losing health care, social security, the social safety net, equal rights for women, blacks, Latinos, etc., more guns everywhere, more poverty etc. You are literally the enemy within.

Mrs. Clinton has had to move her position "to the left" because of Senator Sanders entry into the primaries. If she becomes the nominee, she will do what her husband did: move as the wind blows. If elected, she will solidify her family's position among the world's elite, mostly at the expense of the Sanders constituency.

The conventional wisdom, that she will mash any Republican in the general election, should be more closely examined. Many, like me, who see no meaningful difference between Mrs. Clinton and ANY Republican, will vote for the Republican, in order to force the political situation in America closer to its crisis.

We are sick of business as usual.

That is the most ridiculous and insulting analogy I've ever heard. The presidency requires strong analytical skills and solid knowledge of domestic and foreign affairs. In that sense, a common citizen could be a good president.

Whereas medicine and law require specialized training. It's sad that despite your law degree, this has to be explained.

What is the relevance? You are forgetting that Hillary has been interested and involved in politics and policy making for at least as long as Bill has.

Why do women project their own personal experiences onto other women, and expect them to behave according to their playbook? I'm so happy for you that you and your husband had independent professional lives. Don't see what it has to do with Hillary, or for that matter, any other woman.

I find your last comments to be especially revolting. Her "only earned qualifications" of being a Senator and a Secretary of State are because she managed to glom onto a president? Sexism -- directed against your own gender -- is alive and well.
Excellent logic. You are absolutely right.

My husband was an academic physician, I an attorney. We were married for 45 years. I learned a lot during that time about how medical institutions work, met most of the people he worked with and socialized with them, and vice versa. I cannot imagine that any of the experiences we shared with each other would have qualified my husband to defend a client in court or me to write a research grant proposal.
Hillary managed to bootstrap her marriage to a president and her residency in the White House into an uncontested Senate seat, and later a mediocre term as SOS. Those are her only earned qualifications. Hillary's supporters should recall that Al Gore was Bill Clinton's VP, not Hillary.

Sorry, but the questions he was asked by the Daily News were not "hyper technical." They were substantive, and for someone who has made this his signature issue, if not his only issue, he should be able to discuss it in detailed terms. In fact even if he got asked questions that WERE hyper technical he should be able to participate in the conversation meaningfully. I think it was extremely revealing to see that he had nothing concrete to say that went beyond his stump speech.

Look at it this way. That healthcare plan has helped a lot of Americans who are perhaps, less fortunate than yourself.
How can that be a bad thing???
Just like Obama in 2008.. who got us healthcare.

If Bernie fails to win NY, his best bet at the presidency will be to run as an independent. If Trump does the same when his party tries to shut him out at the convention, Bernie will win the general election and we might actually have a shot at ending the two-party system that has utterly failed the People for the last three decades.

Any Democrat is qualified to be President right now. Has anyone noticed Trump and Cruz? Sanders loses a great deal of his appeal when he attacks a fellow Democrat. They should both be competing in the who-can-beat-Cruz/Trump-the-best, not each other. I like both Sanders and Clinton, but he just lost my support.

The truth is, HR, that there is NOT plenty of time. As someone born and raised in New York, I see that this race for the nomination will be decided this month, and New Yorkers and other in the Northeast watershed states need to take real and sudden notice of how HRC's judgement and decision making is severely lacking, and always has been. All the experience in the world does not necessarily result in good judgement, and qualifications on a resume' are simply not the same as qualifications of character.

I am an ardent Bernie supporter, but am very disappointed with his remark.  He is handing the election to the Republicans by making it more difficult for Bernie fans to switch their allegiance to Hillary should he lose the general election.  He could have said, "Clinton is qualified because of her experiences, but I believe I am more qualified because of my judgment."  He lost the high ground on this one and I hope he can regain it.
